div1.head: Report of Provisional Administration from December 1st 1907 to December 1st 1908, by Charles E. Magoon, [1909]
div1.p: REPUBLIC OF CUBA

REPORT OF PROVISIONAL ADMINISTRATION
FROM DECEMBER 1ST. 1907 TO DECEMBER 1ST. 1908
BY
CHARLES E. MAGOON,
PROVISIONAL GOVERNOR.

HAVANA
----
RAMBLA AND BOUZA, PRINTERS AND STATIONERS
33 AND 35 OBISPO STRET.
1909

DEPARTMENT OF
AGRICULTURE,
INDUSTRY AND
COMMERCE.

The Department of Agriculture, Industry and Commerce
has realized good service to further
the ends for which it was created.
The Section of Agriculture has
issued numerous publications for the spread of knowledge per-
taining to the manner of extending and improving Cuban crops.
Such publications have also been issued by the Agricultural Ex-
periment Station. The Agricultural Exposition held last year,
in connection with the Carnival Festivities, was participated in
by the Section of Agriculture and the Experiment Station and
made a gratifying success. The Section was also active during
the year in distributing vaccine for the inoculation of cattle.

The Section of Industry and Commerce has been engaged
in initiating work for the first industrial census of Cuba. The
Office of Immigration and Colonization has furnished useful in-
formation to immigrants arriving in the country and has found
places for almost 10,000 immigrants during the past year.

The Division of Forests and Mines has completed a map of
Santiago de Cuba, showing the soil and surface conditions, has
assisted in the division of sixteen of the old estates in common
in the eastern Provinces and has demarcated 105 mines.

The Bureau of Trademarks and Patents has had an unusual
amount of routine work which has been despatched with greater
promptness than before, by reason of the introduction of the
card index system and other new methods. The most important
work accomplished was the classification of the records and the
preparation of three albums of trademarks.

The efficiency of the Weather Bureau was increased by its
transfer to a new building especially erected for the purpose at
an advantageous location on the heights overlooking Havana
Bay. The Service has been extended and close relations established
with the United States Weather Bureau. The temporary Fish
Commission attached to this office has satisfactorily resolved
questions which had arisen between the authorities and fisher-
men with respect to the utilization of fisheries on the Cuban
Coast.

The most important sanitary features of the past year have
been:

SANITARY
DEPARTMENT.

1st. The control and final extinction
of yellow fever throughout the territory of the Republic, and,

2nd. The steady progress which has been made by the Na-
tionalized Sanitary Department in municipal sanitation through-
out the Island.

Yellow fewer, which had claimed thousands of victims in
Spanish times, particularly in the cities of Havana and Santia-
go, was suppressed under the Military Government of the
United States. There were no further cases until October 1905,
when it reappeared in Havana, later spreading to other parts of
the Island. One of the tasks of the Provisional Administration
was to combat and extirpate it. Energetic measures, which
necessarily involved the expenditure of large sums of money,
were taken to secure this result. Since effective preventive work
in the municipalities outside of Havana was not practicable so
long as such measures were administered through local sanitary
authorities, the whole sanitary service was nationalized. The
work of fumigation and mosquito prevention was pushed with
such success that in the month of February, 1908, the dread
disease was practically banished from the Island.

Of the seventy-nine cases of yellow fever reported during
the year, fifty-three occurred between the first of November,
1907, and the eighteenth of February, 1908, and are to be con-
sidered as the aftermath of last year's outbreak. Since the latter
date, there has been a local outbreak in the Department of Orien-
te which was promptly brought under control, but no case has
occurred in the five other provinces of the Island, with the ex-
ception of a single sporadic case in Havana on September 7th,
the origin of which has never been satisfactorily determined.
The last case in Havana previous to this one had occurred on
January 30th. The case of September 7th did not, however,
create a focus of infection and was not followed by any
secondary case, although all the non-immunes in that district
of the city were carefully watched for the appearance of
such cases. No case has occurred anywhere in the Island
since that date. In spite of the fact that, with the exception
of this sporadic case in Havana late in the season, yellow
fever did not appear anywhere in Cuban territory except in the
most eastern of the six provinces, where it was easily brought
under control, and would have only justified local quarantine, a
general quarantine was declared against the whole Island by the
United States Public Health and Marine Hospital Service and
was maintained against the three western provinces for a period
143
of four months and against the central provinces of Santa Cla-
ra and Camagüey for a period of five months, during which time
no case of yellow fever occurred in any of these provinces. This
quarantine was declared at a time when no case of yellow fever
had appeared in the Island for seven weeks. Events have there-
fore justified the representations which were made by this Gov-
ernment at the time it was declared that the quarantine was
without reason and was a violation of the sanitary agreement
existing between Cuba and the United States. Such a procedure
seems also a poor requital of the earnest and successful efforts
which have been made by the Cuban people to establish good
sanitary conditions in the Island, in which the Sanitary Depart-
ment has spent during the two years of the Provisional Govern-
ment $1,130,000.00 in the campaign against yellow fever.
There has been spent in addition $2,200,000.00 on general sani-
tary work. The Department of Public Works has during the
same time spent over three and a half millions of dollars on mu-
nicipal sanitary services, not including permanent sanitary works
such as systems of water supply, sewerage and drainage. It is
therefore a very conservative statement to say that the Provi-
sional Government has spent more than one-tenth of the nation-
al income on sanitation.

The thorough character of the campaign against yellow
fever as well as the system of sanitary inspections generally is
shown by the report of the Local Health Officer of Havana. The
city is divided into fifty-two districts, each under an inspector
who makes house to house inspections and is held to a strict re-
sponsibility that no unsanitary conditions, and especially no
breeding places for mosquitoes are overlooked in these inspec-
tions. This inspection extends from roof to cellar and includes
the premises as well as the house. 584,222 house inspections of
this character were made during the past year, being an average
of more than eighteen inspections for each house in the city dur-
ing that period. 1065 deposits of water containing the larvae
of mosquitoes were found in these inspections, and an expert
examination of the larvae showed that 589 of them were the
larvae of stegomyia, the yellow fever carrying variety. This
variety of mosquito is now so rare in Havana that it is believed
that it is impossible for yellow fever to spread if introduced into
the city. With the completion of the sewer system and the aboli-
tion of the cesspools which now exist in connection with almost
144
every house, the prevention of mosquitoes breeding will be great-
ly facilitated, and it is believed that it will be easy to keep the
stegomyia mosquitoes permanently below the yellow fever limit
--that is, below the limit of the number at which the spread of
yellow fever becomes practicable.

The year has been marked by a steady and progressive de-
velopment of the municipal sanitary services which are now con-
ducted by the National Sanitary Department in all the towns of
the Island of over one thousand inhabitants, 137 in number, be-
sides special services in a few of the more important villages
having a less population. The activity of this development is
shown by the fact that equipment and supplies to the value of
$349,326.00 have been purchased and issued to the various mu-
nicipalities exclusive of Havana. In the latter city the service of
street cleaning and removal of garbage has been left temporarily
under the administration of the Department of Public Works.
I am informed by the Chief Sanitary Officer that this develop-
ment of municipal sanitation has resulted in a marked diminu-
tion in the National death rate, and I am satisfied that it has
given great satisfaction to the Cuban people.
REPORT

The victory over yellow fever leaves the Sanitary Depart-
ment free to devote itself to the still greater and more important
war against tuberculosis. This has, however, not been neglected
during the past year, which has seen the completion of the sana-
torium for tuberculosis, La Esperanza, with accommodations for
sixty patients, and the completion of the new, handsome and
commodious building in Havana at the corner of Zulueta and
Apodaca Streets, which is occupied conjointly by the dispensary
for tuberculosis and the Tamayo dispensary for general diseases
The principal needs of this campaign are the establishment of
at least two additional sanatoriums, one in the mountains [unclear]
Santa Clara Province and the other in the province of Orie[unclear]
and the creation of dispensaries for tuberculosis in each of the
larger cities of the Island. A feature essential to efficient w[unclear]
